President Putin has alleged that last week’s deadly unrest in Kazakhstan was carried out by terrorists who had received training in overseas camps, as the leader of the oil-rich central Asian state described the disturbances as a coup attempt.

The Russian president said the violence that killed a reported 164 people bore the hallmarks of a western- coordinated “Maidan” operation, a reference to the protests that deposed Ukraine’s pro-Moscow president in 2014.

 

“Well-organised and well-controlled groups of militants were used,” Putin, 69, told an online meeting of the CSTO, a Moscow-led collective security organisation that consists of six former Soviet states. “[They] had obviously received training in terrorist camps abroad.”

Putin’s claims came as news emerged of the deaths in rapid succession of three highly placed Kazakh security oTcials amid fears of a power struggle.

Protests against a sharp rise in gas prices began just after the new year in western Kazakhstan but rapidly spread to Almaty, the country’s biggest city. Protesters set fire to the city hall and the presidential residence amid clashes with security forces. Putin also said that the CSTO would not allow its member states to be destabilised by “a colour revolution”, the Kremlin’s term for allegedly western- backed uprisings that have overthrown pro-Russian governments in former Soviet states. “We will not allow the boat to be rocked,” he said.

 

Aside from Russia and Kazakhstan, the CSTO consists of Armenia, Belarus, Kyrgyzstan and Tajikistan. Moscow supported President Lukashenko, the Belarusian dictator, after huge protests against his rule in 2020.

 

Putin did not directly accuse western countries of orchestrating the unrest in Kazakhstan. The Kremlin said later that it was up to Kazakhstan, a mainly Muslim country of 19 million people, to identify those forces that it believed were responsible for the violence.

President Tokayev, 68, told Putin that the unrest in his country was an attempted coup that could have been planned for years.

 

“The main goal was obvious: the undermining of the constitutional order, the destruction of government institutions and the seizure of power,” he said. He promised to provide proof to the international community to back up his claims.

Tokayev also alleged that militants had taken advantage of protests in Almaty to attack the city like “a huge cackle of hyenas”.

 

“Militants outnumbered police and army servicemen by at least five times,” Tokayev said. “Two servicemen were beheaded and there were barbaric attacks on hospitals.”

Tokayev denied widespread reports that Kazakh security forces had opened fire on peaceful protesters, but claimed that the terrorists had broken into mortuaries to remove the bodies of their accomplices. “This is how they cover their tracks,” the Kazakh leader said.

 

Karim Masimov, the former Kazakh security service chief and ex-prime minister, was arrested at the weekend and charged with treason amid rumours of infighting among the country’s political elite. Masimov, 56, was dismissed by Tokayev last week at the height of the unrest.

 

This was followed by announcements today of the deaths of three senior Kazakh security oTcials.

 

Zhanat Suleimenov, the head of police in the Jambyl region, where protesters last week clashed with security forces, committed suicide, Interfax reported. Azamat Ibraev, a colonel with the KNB state security agency was found dead in the courtyard of his home in Nur-Sultan, the capital, after apparently falling from a window. Tanat Nazano, a police oTcial in Almaty, died in his oTce of a heart attack, Kazakh media said.

 

A spokesman for Nursultan Nazarbayev, the former president who retains the title “leader of the nation”, said yesterday that he remained in the country and supported Tokayev. Protesters toppled a statue of Nazarbayev, 81, in the unrest.

Russian troops were deployed to Kazakhstan last week after Tokayev appealed to the CSTO for help. Putin said today that they had entered the country to fight “terrorists, marauders and other criminal elements”.

 

Tokayev said yesterday that the deployment of 2,030 CSTO troops was temporary and that it was possible they would leave by the end of this week. Order has now largely been restored in Almaty and other cities.

Nursultan Nazarbayev stepped down as president but retains the title “leader of the nation” in Kazakhstan

 

Facebook has denied that it is aiding censorship in Kazakhstan by allowing the oil- rich former Soviet state to flag “illegal” online content.

The Kazakh government said yesterday that Facebook had agreed to grant it exclusive access to its content reporting system to help identity online posts that may “violate Facebook’s global content policy and local laws”.

 

Kazakhstan, a mainly Muslim country in central Asia, was ruled for almost three decades by Nursultan Nazarbayev until he stepped down as president in 2019. However, Nazarbayev, 81, retained the title “leader of the nation” and has the right to veto government policy.

 

The Kazakh parliament recently began work on legislation that would allow the authorities to cut access to social networks and messaging apps for millions of users unless their developers open oQces in the country.

 

MPs also demanded that Facebook appoint executives to deal with Kazakh government complaints about online posts. About three million of the country’s population of 19 million people are estimated to use Facebook. standards,” he told Reuters. “This process is the same in Kazakhstan as it is for other countries around the world.”

The row follows claims that Apple and Google caved in to pressure from Russia by removing a tactical voting app that was promoted by Alexei Navalny, the jailed opposition leader. Navalny, 45, accused the American companies of being the Kremlin’s “accomplices” after they deleted the app from their online stores in September.
title: Facebook denies helping the Kazakhstan government to censor online content

description:
Women have been shaving their heads in an “attempt to be heard”

 

Female opposition activists in Kazakhstan have been posting videos of themselves shaving their heads on social media to draw attention to the lack of democratic rights in the central Asian country.

 

The European Union has accused Kazakhstan, a former Soviet state, of imprisoning government critics, including journalists. It is also said that torture is widespread in the oil-rich country’s prisons. The mainly Muslim country of 18 million people has been in the news as the homeland of the fictional hero of the new Borat film.

 

Nursultan Nazarbayev stepped down as president last year after almost three decades in oOce. But the strongman leader retained the title Elbasy, “leader of the nation”, a lifetime role that allows him to oversee the elected authorities.

“I live in a prison called Kazakhstan,” said one woman, before cutting oR her long brown hair. “This is my attempt to be heard.” Another woman said: “This is a cry from my soul.”

 

“Our brave activists donated their beautiful hair,” said Dana Zhanay, a government critic. “They demand freedom.”

 

Mr Nazarbayev, 80, is also head of the Security Council, which gives him authority over the armed forces and the police, and chairman of the ruling Nur Otan party, which dominates parliament. MPs voted last year to change the name of the capital from Astana to Nur-Sultan in his honour.

In February an opposition activist, Dulat Agadil, died in police custody amid allegations that he had been tortured to death. OOcials insisted that he had died of natural causes.

Tony Blair advised Mr Nazarbayev following a bloody crackdown on striking oil workers in western Kazakhstan in 2011 that killed 15 people. The former UK prime minister asked for £5 million for his services, leaked documents have shown.
title: Kazakhstan bald protest: female activists say country is a ‘prison’
Kazakhs show they will no longer dance to Moscow’s tune
description:
The vast former Soviet country is trying to loosen its ties with the Kremlin not just politically and economically — but also culturally

 

Growing up in Almaty, Kazakhstan, Asya Tulesova was constantly told that Russia was a superior culture: their leaders were wise, their language sophisticated and their literature, from Pushkin to Dostoevsky, the most beautiful ever published.

 

Kazakh language and culture, she was taught, was crude and unrefined in comparison.

Now, after President Putin’s invasion of Ukraine, Tulesova, 38, is part of a wave of Kazakhs who are turning away from the influence of their former imperial overlords and proudly celebrating their own culture, music and history.

 

In the past year the environmental and political activist has started learning Kazakh, a Turkic language very diNerent from Russian, and when she takes to the stage with her band, We Have to Now, they sing only in Kazakh or English.

 

“If it wasn’t Ukraine [under attack] it could easily be Georgia or us,” she said. “I think many people feel the same way too. It has caused a certain rise in love for [our] culture, and brought all sorts of thoughts about identity.”

 

Tulesova is not alone: after centuries of being dominated by Russia, central Asia is shedding its deference towards Moscow.

In the decades since independence and the fall of the Soviet Union, the region had seen Moscow as a security guarantor: a powerful ally next door whose armed forces could, through shared history and defence agreements, be relied on to protect them. Yet today, many no longer see Russia as a source of stability. The invasion made it very clear: far from keeping them safe, the Russian army was a threat.

 

Nowhere is this change more stark than in Kazakhstan, a country the size of western Europe but with the population of Istanbul, whose oil wealth has made it the richest and most powerful nation in the region.

 

The threat from Russia at its northern border, the second longest in the world at more than 4,700 miles, has even made Kazakhstan’s authoritarian government, led by President Kassym-Jomart Tokayev, a former Soviet diplomat, recalibrate its relationship with Moscow. 

 

Last summer Tokayev publicly refused to back Putin’s “special operation” in Ukraine. In a speech at the United Nations general assembly in September, he criticised the Russian president’s threat to use nuclear weapons. In February Kazakhstan closed a trade mission to Russia, embarrassing the Russian prime minister, Mikhail Mishustin, who was visiting the country at the time.

 

Other world powers are taking note. Nearly 200 years after Britain and Russia fought a diplomatic war of skulduggery and subterfuge over vast territories in central Asia, a new Great Game is afoot.

 

Since spring last year, the wide, empty streets of the Kazakh capital, Astana, have buzzed with diplomats from east and west shuttling back and forth from government ministries with their own pitch on how they would prove to be a better partner than Moscow.

While Kazakhstan has, since independence, claimed to be following a “multi-vector” diplomacy that looks to both east and west, there are now, as one highly placed businessman in the region said, more opportunities opening up for investment, diplomacy and trade.

 

“They’re keeping their options open,” he said. “They are extremely pragmatic. It is a finely tuned, very sophisticated balancing act.”

In February Antony Blinken, the US secretary of state, met leaders of the five central Asian nations in Astana. Last month James Cleverly, the UK foreign secretary, sat down with Tokayev, and posed for photographs in a black mink fur hat and coat while shooting a bow and arrow. Given the depth of Kazakhstan’s relationship with Russia, diplomats say they are remaining realistic about the possibilities for concrete outcomes, but are nonetheless taking advantage of the opening.

 

As well as strengthening ties to the West, Kazakhstan is also working to improve its relations with other Turkic nations, with the aim of creating a trade route westwards over the Caspian Sea that bypasses Russia entirely. It has also signed a deal to start producing Bayraktar drones, deepening its defence co-operation with Ankara.

 

Yet there are limits to what Kazakhstan can do to divest itself from Russia. Despite a public wave of pro- Ukrainian and nationalist sentiment, the country is enormously reliant on Moscow for oil sales, and for the lucrative “parallel market” where western goods can be traded in and out of Russia through Kazakhstan without breaking sanctions.

Last year, for example, exports of semiconductors from Kazakhstan to Russia grew 300-fold from before the war in Ukraine, to a trade worth $3.7 billion (£3 billion). Analysts point out, however, that in recent weeks the Kazakh government has taken steps to tighten controls over trade with Russia.

 

Tokayev was nurtured by his predecessor, Nursultan Nazarbayev, a Soviet Kazakh leader who was made president after independence in 1991, and has been sure to maintain close relations with Russia, including visiting the country several times since the war began.

Some in the Kazakh opposition believe that the perceived opening up to countries other than Russia is just a façade, and that Tokayev is Moscow’s man at heart.

 

“It isn’t a balance I think: co-operation with the West is only by empty words,” said Mukhtar Taizhan, an opposition politician and economics professor. “If we talk about action, we can see the policy of Tokayev towards the Kremlin, towards Russia.”

 

Yet the rhetoric has been striking. In addition to refusing to back the invasion of Ukraine and criticising Moscow’s nuclear brinkmanship, Tokayev has also railed against the “incorrect statements” about Kazakhstan made on Russian state television

 

For months Kremlin mouthpieces have been making territorial claims over Kazakhstan and questioning its right to exist as a nation. Tigran Keosayan, who is married to the head of Kremlin-run propaganda channel RT, accused Kazakhstan of

“ingratitude” after it cancelled a parade celebrating the Soviet victory over Nazi Germany.

 

“Look at Ukraine carefully, think seriously,” he said, in a tirade on his YouTube channel. “Well, I think that responsible persons [in the Kazakh leadership] also need to re-evaluate and revise the level of relations. Because, my dears, if you think that you can continue to be so cunning and get nothing for it, you are mistaken.”

Kazakhstan, Keosayan intimated, should have been more grateful to Russia since it apparently sent 2,000 troops to quash a violent uprising that broke out in the country last year over a rise in gas prices.

 

Hundreds of Kazakhs, including members of the security forces, were killed in the subsequent crackdown, spearheaded by Russian paratroopers.

Tokayev, who claims that the uprising was an attempted coup and promised a series of reforms, kept his job and does not believe he should be grateful to Russia for rescuing him.

 

"In Russia some people distort this whole situation, asserting that Russia supposedly ‘saved’ Kazakhstan, and Kazakhstan should now forever ‘serve and bow down to the feet’ of Russia,” he told the media outlet Rossiya-24. “I believe that these are completely unjustified arguments that are far from reality.”

In Almaty, there is a genuine fear that Russia, desperate for a victory after its battering in Ukraine, might invade part of Kazakhstan under the pretence of aiding ethnic Russians living there.

“I think we are the next target,” said one former opposition politician and analyst, later adding: “Putin needs a war, and an injured animal is more dangerous.”

Diplomats in the region say this is unlikely for now. But the threat hangs constantly over Kazakhstan and its corrupt and underfunded army, which analysts say could not do much to stop a force from Moscow, even one as depleted as the Russians are today.

As the fear of an incursion mounts, tensions have risen between ethnic Kazakhs and ethnic Russians, who make up about 18 per cent of the population.

Although some are pro-Ukrainian, many others watch Russian state television and believe the Kremlin’s conspiracy-ridden rhetoric that paints Ukrainians and anyone else who rejects the Russian government’s world view as Nazis.

 

Since last year, a number of videos and social media posts showing ethnic Russians insulting Kazakhs have gone viral, stoking fears that they could be a potential fifth column for an invasion.

“Our northern cities, they’re like [the Russian-controlled Ukrainian cities of] Donetsk and Luhansk,” said Arman Shorayev, 52, an opposition commentator who comes from the Russian border region. “They’re separatists and collaborators.”

He and many other Kazakhs felt their patience further eroded by the arrival last autumn of more than 200,000 Russians who were escaping mobilisation at home. Although most have now moved to other countries, many Kazakhs feel they have already outstayed their welcome.

 

Amid the rising tensions, Dosym Satpayev, a political scientist, is among those trying to encourage Kazakhs to rediscover their national identity. He is working to publish history books that give context to widely held beliefs, espoused by Russia, that Kazakhstan has no real culture, and that things were better under the Soviet Union.

 

In fact, the Russian tsars battled with the khans — Turkic rulers — for control of this vast, windswept landscape from the 17th century, weathering bloody battles and uprisings before establishing control over what is now Kazakhstan in the 1860s.

When the Bolsheviks seized power, Kazakhstan was forced into collectivised agriculture. The intelligentsia were massacred in the Terror, or, like so many others, were worked or starved to death in the gulags. Grain requisitioning under Stalin resulted in a famine that killed more than a third of all Kazakhs, up to 2.5 million people.

 

“There were a lot of very tragic chapters in our history, and this is one of the instruments to fight with Russian propaganda,” Satpayev said. “Because Mr Putin tried to present Soviet history only as a history of victory . . . but it’s not true.”

The decades-long attempt by the government to promote the Kazakh language has gained ground as young people try to switch away from Russian. Yerbolat Bedelkhan, 43, has been singing in Kazakh in his band, Orda.

“It was very hard [at first] because as you know, the Russian language has integrated strongly with my culture,” he said. “Russian songs were [more] popular than Kazakh music, but now we are conquering the market slowly.”

 

The stuntman and trainer Zhaidarbek Kunguzhinov, 53, who has trained Hollywood actors to fight with swords and fall oN galloping horses, stopped working with Russian actors after the war began. “I think young people are more patriotic now,” he said. “It has changed a lot. What happened in Ukraine unites our nation.”

Calm has returned to the country but it is now waiting to see if President Tokayev will deliver on his promises, writes Marc Bennetts in Almaty

 

In 2010, as he approached twenty years in power, Nursultan Nazarbayev, the leader of Kazakhstan, urged his country’s scientists to develop an “elixir of life”. It was the third occasion in just over a year that the central Asian dictator had called on researchers to invent a way to stave oM death. They did not succeed.

 

More than a decade on, in the aftermath of massive protests that swept Kazakhstan last month, Nazarbayev, now 81 and increasingly frail, is having to come to terms with not only his own mortality but also the end of his iron grip on Kazakhstan, a vast oil-rich former Soviet state located between China and Russia.

 

Although Nazarbayev stepped down as president in 2019, he continued to call the shots from behind the scenes. He handpicked Kassym-Jomart Tokayev, a career diplomat, as his successor and retained the oTcial title of “Elbasy”, or “Leader of the nation”, as well as chairmanship of the powerful security council.

 

He was also the head of the ruling Nur-Otan party, had a veto over domestic and foreign policy, and it was a criminal oMence to insult his “honour and dignity”. If that wasn’t enough, the capital, Astana, a futuristic city that was built almost from scratch out of the Kazakh steppe, was renamed Nur-Sultan in his honour.

 

Demonstrations that erupted in early January in Zhanaozen, a hardscrabble oil town in western Kazakhstan, over a steep rise in gas prices swiftly transformed into nationwide protests against the country’s authoritarian regime. In Almaty, Kazakhstan’s biggest city, protesters chanted “Shal, ket!” which translates as “Old man, leave!”

 

In Taldykorgan, a nearby town, a statue of Nazarbayev was toppled by protesters who attached a noose around its neck and “hanged” it in front of the mayor’s oTce. A list of demands presented by demonstrators in central Almaty called for democratic reforms, including an end to Nazarbayev’s powers. The regime responded with a deadly crackdown.

 

As the protests swelled, President Tokayev, 68, alleged that Almaty was under siege by 20,000 “terrorists” and issued a “shoot-to-kill” order. He also invited Russian troops into the country to help with an anti-terrorist operation. More than 200 people were killed, including unarmed civilians who are said to have been shot dead by security forces. The Kazakh government has yet to provide evidence to back up its claim that Almaty was attacked by foreign-trained militants.

 

The regime may have survived the protests but the unrest signalled the end of Nazarbayev’s role as Kazakhstan’s supreme leader. As gunfire echoed through the streets of Almaty, Tokayev stripped Nazarbayev of his post as head of the security council and appointed himself as his replacement. In addition, Karim Massimov, the Kazakh intelligence chief and one of Nazarbayev’s key allies, was also fired and charged with treason amid rumours of in-fighting among the elite.

 

Nothing was heard of Nazarbayev until almost two weeks after the end of the protests, when he appeared in a short video. Speaking from an unknown location, Nazarbayev insisted that he was still in the country and denied rumours of a power struggle with Tokayev.

 

Describing himself as “pensioner”, he said he was taking a “deserved rest” in the capital, which he pointedly avoided referring to as Nur-Sultan.

 

The video, which was largely viewed as a resignation speech, came shortly before Tokayev ousted Nazarbayev’s three sons-in-law from leading roles at the chamber of commerce, as well as at KazTransOil, the state oil pipeline firm, and QazaqGaz, the Kazakh natural gas pipeline operator.

 

Most significantly, Tokayev also took over as head of the ruling party, while Nazarbayev’s eldest daughter, Dariga, who was once tipped as a future president, was removed from its political council. She remains an MP, but has been on “sick leave” since the protests. Nazarbayev is also set to lose the right to have the final say on government policy, after the move was supported last week by MPs.

 

“This is surely the watershed for Kazakhstan, when it really starts moving into the post-Nazarbayev era — though what that will be like is anyone’s guess,” said Joanna Lillis, the British author of Dark Shadows, a book about recent Kazakh history.

There are more symbolic signs, too, that the epoch of Nazarbayev has come to an end. The statue of the Kazakh leader that was toppled during the protests has yet to be to replaced or repaired, and there are no indications that it ever will be. On Almaty’s Nazarbayev Avenue, a street sign that was pulled down by angry protesters lies forgotten on a street corner.

 

“Nazarbayev knows what the people really think about him now,” said Aset Abishev, a former political prisoner.

In the aftermath of the protests, Tokayev has also criticised Kazakhstan’s gross economic inequality, admitting last month that just 162 people owned more than half of the country’s wealth. He vowed that the country’s richest individuals and companies would be forced to donate to a fund that would be used to tackle poverty and promised to announce a package of political reforms in September. Yet critics say that while Nazarbayev may have been stripped of many of his powers, there is little hope of meaningful change.

 

“Nazarbayev and his family could not remain in power, otherwise it will not be possible to stabilise the situation after the protests,” said Dimash Alzhanov, a political analyst. “But the nature of the regime has not changed.”

Opposition figures also say that neighbouring Russia is unlikely to welcome genuine reform in Kazakhstan over concerns that this would inspire supporters of democratic change in Moscow. While Kazakhstan has been happy to do business with western oil companies such as BP and Shell, it has strong ties with President Putin’s regime. Those links are now likely to grow further after Tokayev called in Russian troops to help quash last month’s protests.

 

“Even if Tokayev wants to start democratic changes, Putin does not want to have models of democracy for Russians in central Asia,” said Zhanbolat Mamay, an opposition figure. “I do not think Russia will allow him to begin any real reforms.”

Britain has also been accused of hindering Kazakhstan’s development by doing too little to prevent the flow of “dirty money” into the London property market. Nazarbayev and his extended family, described as “grossly kleptocratic” by William Courtney, a former US ambassador to Kazakhstan, are estimated to own at least £530 million of luxury real estate in the UK, according to a recent report by the Chatham House think tank. These properties include 221b Baker Street, the residence in London that served as Sherlock Holmes’s fictional home, and Sunninghill, a Berkshire mansion that was purchased from Prince Andrew in 2007 for £15 million.

 

“We have opened our borders, our property market and our financial structures to the Kazakh ruling class, enabling them to launder their illicit wealth and spend it,” Margaret Hodge, the Labour MP, said in parliament last week, as calls grew for the government to impose sanctions on Nazarbayev and his family. “The recent violence demonstrates the true cost of kleptocracy”

 

Calm has returned to the streets of Almaty since last month’s protests, but there is a sense that the country is holding its collective breath to see if Tokayev can or will deliver on his promises. The stakes are high, warned Alzhanov, the analyst. “Without serious reforms, sooner or later, society will explode again.”
title: Kazakhstan holds its breath and waits for reform after protests
